I've been aching to reply to this post for a while, and I finally  
have enough free time to do so. I think we could have a really  
interesting discussion here, hopefully at least more interesting than  
the NFL tangent.

>> Sure, but tile-coding does respect at least one form of geometry:
>> Nearby elements in the state space are known to be nearby, and thus
>> are grouped in the same tile.
>
> I have to dispute this characterization of tile coding
> as "respecting at least one form of geometry." I think you are
> being unnecessarily equitable toward tile coding.
>
> What you are saying is that in effect taking a nice sculpture and
> cutting it into pieces "respects" its geometry because those little
> pieces are not broken up any further than that. It's like saying
> that someone who cut your head off "respected" your head by keeping
> its internal integrity intact. In fact, tile coding is peforming a
> grievous violation against the existing geometry of the domain, and
> does not deserve to be credited with respecting geometry
> whatsoever. I'm hard pressed to imagine how one could do worse
> beyond cutting things up into even tinier and tinier bits; but even
> then, those bits still contain "nearby elements in the state
> space." So that isn't saying much.

Yeah, from the way your framing this argument, e.g. tile-coding used  
in the GA model-selection sense, you're absolutely right. I'll get  
back to exactly what I mean by that in a bit. For now lets try to  
reframe the issue from an RL perspective, which is where tile-codings  
are predominantly used. In RL, the tile-coding is just a  
representation for a function approximator (in a sense its sort of  
like a really simple spline cure) that learns in a supervised manner.  
Tile coding makes a lot of sense in this domain because you can  
calculate with a good deal of precision how much some particular tile  
differs from the expected value of the function being approximated  
(in this case the Bellman error).
Tiles hat is cover a broad area where the value function changes a  
lot ("have bad fit", "are too general", etc) are then split so that  
the subtiles can better fit the value function being learned. Note  
that there is very little generalization desired here; the best thing  
given infinite computational resources would be to have a whole ton  
of itty-bitty tiles that fit the value function perfectly.

Anyway, since we're in the standard RL framework, there is really no  
way of learning the "geometry" of a value function (well, technically  
there is, but thats a long tangent towards a really interesting  
research area). Maybe if the geometry was given by the experimenter  
beforehand (this would also lead to an interesting extension of tile- 
codings that you might like a little better). But in any case, since  
all we're trying to do in RL is supervised function approximation,  
the lack of geometry isn't bad.


> I'm obviously not a big fan of tile coding :) I'm not really
> concerned whether it might do better in some cases; the problem with
> it is that it is a dead end for future progress because it is about
> ruining our ability to exploit geometric relationships.

Ok, this is where the discussion gets really interesting. Remember  
when I mentioned GA's "performing model selection" or something like  
that before? Thats a fundamental difference in the GA approach and  
RL. So what do I mean by model selection: roughly speaking, in  
Bayesian inference you have this idea of some separation of the  
parameters you are optimizing (e.g. the weights in an NN) and the  
model that generates those parameters (e.g. the topology of the NN,  
or even whether you use an NN or decision tree or something). RL is  
inherently incapable of performing model selection (at least outside  
of NEAT+Q and some others). Once you start learning with  a given  
value function representation, you can no longer switch to a  
different representation without throwing away everything you've just  
learned.  GAs on the other hand learn one parameterized model per  
individual. This is an important distinction.

Now, what does this have to do with tile coding and learning  
geometry?  When you talk about "cutting up different variables" you  
are inherently making an argument from the standpoint of model  
selection: i.e. what is the best representation for this learning  
problem? This is a valid question in the GA world, and I agree with  
you tile coding wouldn't work at all for learning good  
representations that allow good future learning. But from the RL  
standpoint, since all tile-coding is used for is function  
approximation, I don't think they are as problematic as you imagine.

-- Joe
